response.raw_message_text:
{
  "risk_factors": [
    ("Criminal History", "medium", "Two arrests with conviction indicate a prior record, which elevates risk relative to no prior convictions but is not extremely high compared to cases with higher counts."),
    ("Demographics", "low", "Being a 21-year-old male and Black does not strongly predict recidivism on its own based on these examples."),
    ("Physical Attributes", "low", "The height of 6'4\" and weight of 210 lbs do not seem to associate strongly with increased risk."),
    ("Marital and Living Status", "medium", "Never married and living alone have been seen in both low and high risk cases, suggesting moderate influence."),
    ("Education and College Enrollment", "low", "Having a high school diploma and being enrolled in a 4-year college appears protective in several examples."),
    ("Employment", "medium", "Holding 1 job during the year is average and neither increases nor decreases risk dramatically."),
    ("Substance Use", "medium", "Marijuana use in the past four years adds some risk, though it is less severe compared to multi-drug use scenarios."),
    ("Depression", "low", "Not feeling depressed in the past month is a protective factor, decreasing risk."),
    ("Early Social Environment", "medium", "Growing up with the biological mother in a large urban household (size of 7) has mixed implications, suggesting moderate risk."),
    ("Religious Belief", "low", "Attributing events to God's influence is common across examples and does not strongly differentiate risk levels.")
  ],
  "prediction": "NO",
  "confidence": 75
}

risk_factors: Two arrests with conviction indicate a prior record, which elevates risk relative to no prior convictions but is not extremely high compared to cases with higher counts.
Being a 21-year-old male and Black does not strongly predict recidivism on its own based on these examples.
The height of 6'4" and weight of 210 lbs do not seem to associate strongly with increased risk.
Never married and living alone have been seen in both low and high risk cases, suggesting moderate influence.
Having a high school diploma and being enrolled in a 4-year college appears protective in several examples.
Holding 1 job during the year is average and neither increases nor decreases risk dramatically.
Marijuana use in the past four years adds some risk, though it is less severe compared to multi-drug use scenarios.
Not feeling depressed in the past month is a protective factor, decreasing risk.
Growing up with the biological mother in a large urban household (size of 7) has mixed implications, suggesting moderate risk.
Attributing events to God's influence is common across examples and does not strongly differentiate risk levels.

prompt.system:
You are a highly experienced criminal justice risk assessment expert
employing advanced statistical and judicial knowledge.
prompt.user:
You are a criminal risk assessment expert. First,analyze the following example cases of risk factors and resulting 3 year rearrest recidivism outcome:

Example #1:
Risk Factors: The person is a 21-year-old male who identifies himself as White. He has been arrested 1 time but has not been convicted. He is 6 feet 5 inches and weighs over 250 lbs. He has never been married and is currently living alone. He has a high school diploma and is not enrolled in college. He has held 2 jobs during the year. He has used drugs in the past four years (marijuana) and has not felt depressed over the past month. At a young age, he lived with both of his biological parents in a household of size 7, in an urban area. He considers that God has something to do with what happens to him personally.
Outcome: NO

Risk Factors: The person is an 18-year-old male who identifies himself as Black. He has been arrested 1 time but has not been convicted. He is 5 feet 7 inches and weighs 140 lbs. He has not used any drugs in the past four years and has not felt depressed over the past month. At a young age, he lived with his biological mother in a household of size 4, in an urban area. He considers that God has something to do with what happens to him personally.
Outcome: NO
